bioghist.p: John Nichols, was an apprentice to William Bowyer the younger (1699-1777), one of London’s most learned and influential printers. In 1766 Nichols became Bowyer’s partner and inherited the business on Bowyer’s death. He continued Bowyer’s tradition of printing for private gentlemen, learned societies and the Palace of Westminster and, in 1778, purchased a share in the Gentleman’s Magazine, a popular monthly periodical specializing in literature, history and the arts. The Nichols family edited and printed the magazine until 1856. His son, John Bowyer Nichols entered the firm in 1796 and conducted the business beginning in 1803.

scopecontent.p: These 131 letters are from the files of the London publishing firm of John Nichols and Sons. The letters are from authors and business firms having dealings with the publisher. They represent only "K" and "L" from the files, and cover the period from 1770 to 1820. There are some copies of Nichols' answers. The letters in general have to do with biographies, articles for Gentlemen's Magazine and Legal Antiquities, illustrations for articles, and requests for books.
